take: suspending judgment sounds wise but it's actually stagnation. shoot from the hip — even bad takes get you free lessons from people who know more. it's fine to be confidently wrong as long as you update fast. in high-stakes situations, checks and balances belong on the interaction, not the individual. hold your opinions loosely, but have them.
the people most worried about ai are often the ones who understand it best. that should tell you something.

most people would rather be comfortably numb than stare into the abyss. the resistance isn't fear of failure — it's that not reaching lets you avoid the discomfort of honest self-assessment. build a culture where ambition is normal and you remove the excuse.

the future isn't something that happens to us. everyone designs who devises courses of action aimed at changing existing situations into preferred ones — that's herbert simon. the question is whether we're designing deliberately or sleepwalking.

the bar for giving feedback should be low. it's on the receiver to sit with it, separate signal from noise, and grow. both sides have to be able to shoot from the hip — and then be grown up enough to work through the friction, do the three-way handshake, and come out wiser together.

being explicit doesn't kill the magic — it deepens it. passion gives you the irrational commitment to reason through hard things clearly. those who say mystery is necessary are putting the cart before the horse — both passionate intuition and explicit reason matter, and they compound each other.

work-life balance is the wrong frame. if your work is a labor of love, it should be deeply integrated with your life — there are massive economies of scope and scale when the same curiosity drives your work, your relationships, and your play.

diplomats currently do too much vibes and not enough strategy. we need less empathy-as-performance and more specialization, confrontation, and hard discussions. the difficult conversations are the ones that actually move things.

don't blame politicians for being self-serving — blame the incentive landscape that rewards it. we could incentivize them to admit mistakes and update their beliefs. judge them on whether they're good tinkerers with a strong moral compass — not on whether every bet paid off.
